member.name: T:WinUtilities.WM
member.summary: Enum of all Window Messages.

member.name: T:WinUtilities.WS
member.summary: Enum of all Window Styles.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.BORDER
member.summary: The window has a thin-line border.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.CAPTION
member.summary: The window has a title bar (includes the WS_BORDER style).

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.CHILD
member.summary: The window is a child window. A window with this style cannot have a menu bar. This style cannot be used with the WS_POPUP style.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.CLIPCHILDREN
member.summary: Excludes the area occupied by child windows when drawing occurs within the parent window. This style is used when creating the parent window.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.CLIPSIBLINGS
member.summary: Clips child windows relative to each other; that is, when a particular child window receives a WM_PAINT message, the WS_CLIPSIBLINGS style clips all other overlapping child windows out of the region of the child window to be updated. If WS_CLIPSIBLINGS is not specified and child windows overlap, it is possible, when drawing within the client area of a child window, to draw within the client area of a neighboring child window.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.DISABLED
member.summary: The window is initially disabled. A disabled window cannot receive input from the user. To change this after a window has been created, use the EnableWindow function.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.DLGFRAME
member.summary: The window has a border of a style typically used with dialog boxes. A window with this style cannot have a title bar.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.GROUP
member.summary: The window is the first control of a group of controls. The group consists of this first control and all controls defined after it, up to the next control with the WS_GROUP style. The first control in each group usually has the WS_TABSTOP style so that the user can move from group to group. The user can subsequently change the keyboard focus from one control in the group to the next control in the group by using the direction keys. You can turn this style on and off to change dialog box navigation. To change this style after a window has been created, use the SetWindowLong function.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.HSCROLL
member.summary: The window has a horizontal scroll bar.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.MAXIMIZE
member.summary: The window is initially maximized.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.MAXIMIZEBOX
member.summary: The window has a maximize button. Cannot be combined with the WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP style. The WS_SYSMENU style must also be specified.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.MINIMIZE
member.summary: The window is initially minimized.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.MINIMIZEBOX
member.summary: The window has a minimize button. Cannot be combined with the WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP style. The WS_SYSMENU style must also be specified.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.OVERLAPPED
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. An overlapped window has a title bar and a border.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.POPUP
member.summary: The window is a pop-up window. This style cannot be used with the WS_CHILD style.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.SIZEFRAME
member.summary: The window has a sizing border.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.SYSMENU
member.summary: The window has a window menu on its title bar. The WS_CAPTION style must also be specified.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.TABSTOP
member.summary: The window is a control that can receive the keyboard focus when the user presses the TAB key. Pressing the TAB key changes the keyboard focus to the next control with the WS_TABSTOP style. You can turn this style on and off to change dialog box navigation. To change this style after a window has been created, use the SetWindowLong function. For user-created windows and modeless dialogs to work with tab stops, alter the message loop to call the IsDialogMessage function.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.VISIBLE
member.summary: The window is initially visible. This style can be turned on and off by using the ShowWindow or SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS.VSCROLL
member.summary: The window has a vertical scroll bar.

member.name: T:WinUtilities.WS_EX
member.summary: Enum of all Window Ex Styles.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.ACCEPTFILES
member.summary: Specifies a window that accepts drag-drop files.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.APPWINDOW
member.summary: Forces a top-level window onto the taskbar when the window is visible.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.CLIENTEDGE
member.summary: Specifies a window that has a border with a sunken edge.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.COMPOSITED
member.summary: Specifies a window that paints all descendants in bottom-to-top painting order using double-buffering. This cannot be used if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC. This style is not supported in Windows 2000.
member.remarks: With WS_EX_COMPOSITED set, all descendants of a window get bottom-to-top painting order using double-buffering. Bottom-to-top painting order allows a descendent window to have translucency (alpha) and transparency (color-key) effects, but only if the descendent window also has the WS_EX_TRANSPARENT bit set. Double-buffering allows the window and its descendents to be painted without flicker.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.CONTEXTHELP
member.summary: Specifies a window that includes a question mark in the title bar. When the user clicks the question mark, the cursor changes to a question mark with a pointer. If the user then clicks a child window, the child receives a WM_HELP message. The child window should pass the message to the parent window procedure, which should call the WinHelp function using the HELP_WM_HELP command. The Help application displays a pop-up window that typically contains help for the child window. WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP cannot be used with the WS_MAXIMIZEBOX or WS_MINIMIZEBOX styles.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.CONTROLPARENT
member.summary: Specifies a window which contains child windows that should take part in dialog box navigation. If this style is specified, the dialog manager recurses into children of this window when performing navigation operations such as handling the TAB key, an arrow key, or a keyboard mnemonic.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.DLGMODALFRAME
member.summary: Specifies a window that has a double border.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.LAYERED
member.summary: Specifies a window that is a layered window. This cannot be used for child windows or if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.LAYOUTRTL
member.summary: Specifies a window with the horizontal origin on the right edge. Increasing horizontal values advance to the left. The shell language must support reading-order alignment for this to take effect.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.LEFT
member.summary: Specifies a window that has generic left-aligned properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.LEFTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: Specifies a window with the vertical scroll bar (if present) to the left of the client area. The shell language must support reading-order alignment for this to take effect.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.LTRREADING
member.summary: Specifies a window that displays text using left-to-right reading-order properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.MDICHILD
member.summary: Specifies a multiple-document interface (MDI) child window.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.NOACTIVATE
member.summary: Specifies a top-level window created with this style does not become the foreground window when the user clicks it. The system does not bring this window to the foreground when the user minimizes or closes the foreground window. The window does not appear on the taskbar by default. To force the window to appear on the taskbar, use the WS_EX_APPWINDOW style. To activate the window, use the SetActiveWindow or SetForegroundWindow function.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.NOINHERITLAYOUT
member.summary: Specifies a window which does not pass its window layout to its child windows.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.NOPARENTNOTIFY
member.summary: Specifies that a child window created with this style does not send the WM_PARENTNOTIFY message to its parent window when it is created or destroyed.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.NOREDIRECTIONBITMAP
member.summary: The window does not render to a redirection surface. This is for windows that do not have visible content or that use mechanisms other than surfaces to provide their visual.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.RIGHT
member.summary: Specifies a window that has generic "right-aligned" properties. This depends on the window class. The shell language must support reading-order alignment for this to take effect. Using the WS_EX_RIGHT style has the same effect as using the SS_RIGHT (static), ES_RIGHT (edit), and BS_RIGHT/BS_RIGHTBUTTON (button) control styles.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.RIGHTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: Specifies a window with the vertical scroll bar (if present) to the right of the client area. This is the default.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.RTLREADING
member.summary: Specifies a window that displays text using right-to-left reading-order properties. The shell language must support reading-order alignment for this to take effect.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.STATICEDGE
member.summary: Specifies a window with a three-dimensional border style intended to be used for items that do not accept user input.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.TOOLWINDOW
member.summary: Specifies a window that is intended to be used as a floating toolbar. A tool window has a title bar that is shorter than a normal title bar, and the window title is drawn using a smaller font. A tool window does not appear in the taskbar or in the dialog that appears when the user presses ALT+TAB. If a tool window has a system menu, its icon is not displayed on the title bar. However, you can display the system menu by right-clicking or by typing ALT+SPACE.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.TOPMOST
member.summary: Specifies a window that should be placed above all non-topmost windows and should stay above them, even when the window is deactivated. To add or remove this style, use the SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.TRANSPARENT
member.summary: Specifies a window that should not be painted until siblings beneath the window (that were created by the same thread) have been painted. The window appears transparent because the bits of underlying sibling windows have already been painted. To achieve transparency without these restrictions, use the SetWindowRgn function.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WS_EX.WINDOWEDGE
member.summary: Specifies a window that has a border with a raised edge.

member.name: M:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SetParent(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Changes the parent window of the specified child window
member.param: A handle to the child window
A handle to the new parent window. If this parameter is NULL, the desktop window becomes the new parent window. If this parameter is HWND_MESSAGE, the child window becomes a message-only window.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.KeyMapFlags.VirtualKey_to_ScanCode
member.summary: The uCode parameter is a virtual-key code and is translated into a scan code. If it is a virtual-key code that does not distinguish between left- and right-hand keys, the left-hand scan code is returned. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.KeyMapFlags.ScanCode_to_VirtualKey
member.summary: The uCode parameter is a scan code and is translated into a virtual-key code that does not distinguish between left- and right-hand keys. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.KeyMapFlags.ScanCode_to_Char
member.summary: The uCode parameter is a virtual-key code and is translated into an unshifted character value in the low order word of the return value. Dead keys (diacritics) are indicated by setting the top bit of the return value. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.KeyMapFlags.ScanCode_to_VirtualKeyEx
member.summary: The uCode parameter is a scan code and is translated into a virtual-key code that distinguishes between left- and right-hand keys. If there is no translation, the function returns 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.ByteAlignClient
member.summary: Aligns the window's client area on a byte boundary (in the x direction). This style affects the width of the window and its horizontal placement on the display.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.ByteAlignWindow
member.summary: Aligns the window on a byte boundary (in the x direction). This style affects the width of the window and its horizontal placement on the display.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.ClassDC
member.summary: Allocates one device context to be shared by all windows in the class. Because window classes are process specific, it is possible for multiple threads of an application to create a window of the same class. It is also possible for the threads to attempt to use the device context simultaneously. When this happens, the system allows only one thread to successfully finish its drawing operation.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.DoubleClicks
member.summary: Sends a double-click message to the window procedure when the user double-clicks the mouse while the cursor is within a window belonging to the class.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.DropShadow
member.summary: Enables the drop shadow effect on a window. The effect is turned on and off through SPI_SETDROPSHADOW. Typically, this is enabled for small, short-lived windows such as menus to emphasize their Z order relationship to other windows.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.GlobalClass
member.summary: Indicates that the window class is an application global class. For more information, see the "Application Global Classes" section of About Window Classes.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.HorizontalRedraw
member.summary: Redraws the entire window if a movement or size adjustment changes the width of the client area.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.NoClose
member.summary: Disables Close on the window menu.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.OwnDC
member.summary: Allocates a unique device context for each window in the class.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.ParentDC
member.summary: Sets the clipping rectangle of the child window to that of the parent window so that the child can draw on the parent. A window with the CS_PARENTDC style bit receives a regular device context from the system's cache of device contexts. It does not give the child the parent's device context or device context settings. Specifying CS_PARENTDC enhances an application's performance.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.SaveBits
member.summary: Saves, as a bitmap, the portion of the screen image obscured by a window of this class. When the window is removed, the system uses the saved bitmap to restore the screen image, including other windows that were obscured. Therefore, the system does not send WM_PAINT messages to windows that were obscured if the memory used by the bitmap has not been discarded and if other screen actions have not invalidated the stored image. This style is useful for small windows (for example, menus or dialog boxes) that are displayed briefly and then removed before other screen activity takes place. This style increases the time required to display the window, because the system must first allocate memory to store the bitmap.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.ClassStyles.VerticalRedraw
member.summary: Redraws the entire window if a movement or size adjustment changes the height of the client area.

member.name: T:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WH
member.summary: Enum of Windows Hooks

member.name: T:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM
member.summary: Enum of System Metrics

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.ARRANGE
member.summary: The flags that specify how the system arranged minimized windows. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CLEANBOOT
member.summary: The value that specifies how the system is started: 0 Normal boot 1 Fail-safe boot 2 Fail-safe with network boot A fail-safe boot (also called SafeBoot, Safe Mode, or Clean Boot) bypasses the user startup files.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CMONITORS
member.summary: The number of display monitors on a desktop. For more information, see the Remarks section in this topic.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CMOUSEBUTTONS
member.summary: The number of buttons on a mouse, or zero if no mouse is installed.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXBORDER
member.summary: The width of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the CXEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXCURSOR
member.summary: The width of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as CXFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The width of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. , The second click must occur within the rectangle that is defined by CXDOUBLECLK and CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time. To set the width of the double-click rectangle, call SystemParametersInfo with SPI_SETDOUBLECLKWIDTH.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels on either side of a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from the left of the mouse-down point and added to the right of it.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXEDGE
member.summary: The width of a 3-D border, in pixels. This metric is the 3-D counterpart of CXBORDER.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border, and CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as CXDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The width of the left and right edges of the focus rectangle that the DrawFocusRectdraws. This value is in pixels. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as CXSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen that is not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfofunction with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXHSCROLL
member.summary: The width of the arrow bitmap on a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXHTHUMB
member.summary: The width of the thumb box in a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXICON
member.summary: The default width of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions that CXICON and CYICON specifies.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXICONSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size CXICONSPACING by CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to CXICON.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default width, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum width of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXMENUCHECK
member.summary: The width of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXMENUSIZE
member.summary: The width of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXMIN
member.summary: The minimum width of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXMINIMIZED
member.summary: The width of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXMINSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to CXMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking width of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXPADDEDBORDER
member.summary: The amount of border padding for captioned windows, in pixels. Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, HORZRES).

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXSIZE
member.summary: The width of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as CXFRAME.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXSMICON
member.summary: The recommended width of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXSMSIZE
member.summary: The width of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The XVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CXVSCROLL
member.summary: The width of a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYBORDER
member.summary: The height of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the CYEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a caption area, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYCURSOR
member.summary: The height of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as CYFIXEDFRAME.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The height of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. The second click must occur within the rectangle defined by CXDOUBLECLK and CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time. To set the height of the double-click rectangle, call SystemParametersInfo with SPI_SETDOUBLECLKHEIGHT.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels above and below a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from above the mouse-down point and added below it.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYEDGE
member.summary: The height of a 3-D border, in pixels. This is the 3-D counterpart of CYBORDER.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border, and CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as CYDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The height of the top and bottom edges of the focus rectangle drawn byDrawFocusRect. This value is in pixels. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as CYSIZEFRAME.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYHSCROLL
member.summary: The height of a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYICON
member.summary: The default height of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions CXICON and CYICON.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYICONSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size CXICONSPACING by CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to CYICON.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYKANJIWINDOW
member.summary: For double byte character set versions of the system, this is the height of the Kanji window at the bottom of the screen, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default height, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum height of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMENU
member.summary: The height of a single-line menu bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMENUCHECK
member.summary: The height of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMENUSIZE
member.summary: The height of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMIN
member.summary: The minimum height of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMINIMIZED
member.summary: The height of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMINSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to CYMINIMIZED.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking height of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, VERTRES).

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYSIZE
member.summary: The height of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as CYFRAME.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYSMCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a small caption, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYSMICON
member.summary: The recommended height of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYSMSIZE
member.summary: The height of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The YVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the coordinates for the top of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYVSCROLL
member.summary: The height of the arrow bitmap on a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.CYVTHUMB
member.summary: The height of the thumb box in a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.DBCSENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if User32.dll supports DBCS; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.DEBUG
member.summary: Nonzero if the debug version of User.exe is installed; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.DIGITIZER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The return value is a bitmask that specifies the type of digitizer input supported by the device. For more information, see Remarks. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.IMMENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if Input Method Manager/Input Method Editor features are enabled; otherwise, 0. IMMENABLED indicates whether the system is ready to use a Unicode-based IME on a Unicode application. To ensure that a language-dependent IME works, check DBCSENABLED and the system ANSI code page. Otherwise the ANSI-to-Unicode conversion may not be performed correctly, or some components like fonts or registry settings may not be present.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.MAXIMUMTOUCHES
member.summary: Nonzero if there are digitizers in the system; otherwise, 0. MAXIMUMTOUCHES returns the aggregate maximum of the maximum number of contacts supported by every digitizer in the system. If the system has only single-touch digitizers, the return value is 1. If the system has multi-touch digitizers, the return value is the number of simultaneous contacts the hardware can provide. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, and Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.MEDIACENTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP, Media Center Edition, 0 if not.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.MENUDROPALIGNMENT
member.summary: Nonzero if drop-down menus are right-aligned with the corresponding menu-bar item; 0 if the menus are left-aligned.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.MIDEASTENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if the system is enabled for Hebrew and Arabic languages, 0 if not.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.MOUSEPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse is installed; otherwise, 0. This value is rarely zero, because of support for virtual mice and because some systems detect the presence of the port instead of the presence of a mouse.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.MOUSEHORIZONTALWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a horizontal scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.MOUSEWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a vertical scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.NETWORK
member.summary: The least significant bit is set if a network is present; otherwise, it is cleared. The other bits are reserved for future use.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.PENWINDOWS
member.summary: Nonzero if the Microsoft Windows for Pen computing extensions are installed; zero otherwise.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.REMOTECONTROL
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment to determine if the current Terminal Server session is being remotely controlled. Its value is nonzero if the current session is remotely controlled; otherwise, 0. You can use terminal services management tools such as Terminal Services Manager (tsadmin.msc) and shadow.exe to control a remote session. When a session is being remotely controlled, another user can view the contents of that session and potentially interact with it.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.REMOTESESSION
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment. If the calling process is associated with a Terminal Services client session, the return value is nonzero. If the calling process is associated with the Terminal Services console session, the return value is 0. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: The console session is not necessarily the physical console. For more information, seeWTSGetActiveConsoleSessionId.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.SAMEDISPLAYFORMAT
member.summary: Nonzero if all the display monitors have the same color format, otherwise, 0. Two displays can have the same bit depth, but different color formats. For example, the red, green, and blue pixels can be encoded with different numbers of bits, or those bits can be located in different places in a pixel color value.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.SECURE
member.summary: This system metric should be ignored; it always returns 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.SERVERR2
member.summary: The build number if the system is Windows Server 2003 R2; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.SHOWSOUNDS
member.summary: Nonzero if the user requires an application to present information visually in situations where it would otherwise present the information only in audible form; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.SHUTTINGDOWN
member.summary: Nonzero if the current session is shutting down; otherwise, 0. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.SLOWMACHINE
member.summary: Nonzero if the computer has a low-end (slow) processor; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.STARTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 Starter Edition, Windows Vista Starter, or Windows XP Starter Edition; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.SWAPBUTTON
member.summary: Nonzero if the meanings of the left and right mouse buttons are swapped; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.TABLETPC
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP Tablet PC edition or if the current operating system is Windows Vista or Windows 7 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The DIGITIZER setting indicates the type of digitizer input supported by a device running Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2. For more information, see Remarks.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.XVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The CXVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the width of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.SM.YVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the top of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The CYVIRTUALSCREEN metric is the height of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.RegionType.Error
member.summary: Region does not exist or an error occurred.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.RegionType.Null
member.summary: Region is empty.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.RegionType.Simple
member.summary: Region consists of one rectangle.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.RegionType.Complex
member.summary: Region is a complex shape.

member.name: T:WinUtilities.WinAPI.FillRgnFlags
member.summary: Documentation here

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.AsyncWindowPos
member.summary: If the calling thread and the thread that owns the window are attached to different input queues, the system posts the request to the thread that owns the window. This prevents the calling thread from blocking its execution while other threads process the request.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.DeferErase
member.summary: Prevents generation of the WM_SYNCPAINT message.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.DrawFrame
member.summary: Draws a frame (defined in the window's class description) around the window.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.FrameChanged
member.summary: Applies new frame styles set using the SetWindowLong function. Sends a WM_NCCALCSIZE message to the window, even if the window's size is not being changed. If this flag is not specified, WM_NCCALCSIZE is sent only when the window's size is being changed.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.HideWindow
member.summary: Hides the window.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoActivate
member.summary: Does not activate the window. If this flag is not set, the window is activated and moved to the top of either the topmost or non-topmost group (depending on the setting of the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoCopyBits
member.summary: Discards the entire contents of the client area. If this flag is not specified, the valid contents of the client area are saved and copied back into the client area after the window is sized or repositioned.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoMove
member.summary: Retains the current position (ignores X and Y parameters).

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoOwnerZOrder
member.summary: Does not change the owner window's position in the Z order.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoRedraw
member.summary: Does not redraw changes. If this flag is set, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of the window being moved. When this flag is set, the application must explicitly invalidate or redraw any parts of the window and parent window that need redrawing.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoReposition
member.summary: Same as the SWP_NOOWNERZORDER flag.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoSendChangingEvent
member.summary: Prevents the window from receiving the WM_WINDOWPOSCHANGING message.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoSize
member.summary: Retains the current size (ignores the cx and cy parameters).

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.NoZOrder
member.summary: Retains the current Z order (ignores the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.WindowPosFlags.ShowWindow
member.summary: Displays the window.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.AncestorFlags.GetParent
member.summary: Retrieves the parent window. This does not include the owner, as it does with the GetParent function.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.AncestorFlags.GetRoot
member.summary: Retrieves the root window by walking the chain of parent windows.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.AncestorFlags.GetRootOwner
member.summary: Retrieves the owned root window by walking the chain of parent and owner windows returned by GetParent.

member.name: T:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations
member.summary: Specifies a raster-operation code. These codes define how the color data for the source rectangle is to be combined with the color data for the destination rectangle to achieve the final color.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.SRCCOPY
member.summary: dest = source

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.SRCPAINT
member.summary: dest = source OR dest

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.SRCAND
member.summary: dest = source AND dest

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.SRCINVERT
member.summary: dest = source XOR dest

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.SRCERASE
member.summary: dest = source AND (NOT dest)

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.NOTSRCCOPY
member.summary: dest = (NOT source)

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.NOTSRCERASE
member.summary: dest = (NOT src) AND (NOT dest)

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.MERGECOPY
member.summary: dest = (source AND pattern)

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.MERGEPAINT
member.summary: dest = (NOT source) OR dest

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.PATCOPY
member.summary: dest = pattern

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.PATPAINT
member.summary: dest = DPSnoo

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.PATINVERT
member.summary: dest = pattern XOR dest

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.DSTINVERT
member.summary: dest = (NOT dest)

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.BLACKNESS
member.summary: dest = BLACK

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.WHITENESS
member.summary: dest = WHITE

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.TernaryRasterOperations.CAPTUREBLT
member.summary: Capture window as seen on screen. This includes layered windows such as WPF windows with AllowsTransparency="true"

member.name: T:WinUtilities.WinAPI.MONITORINFOEX
member.summary: The MONITORINFOEX structure contains information about a display monitor. The GetMonitorInfo function stores information into a MONITORINFOEX structure or a MONITORINFO structure. The MONITORINFOEX structure is a superset of the MONITORINFO structure. The MONITORINFOEX structure adds a string member to contain a name for the display monitor.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.MONITORINFOEX.Size
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the structure. Set this member to sizeof(MONITORINFOEX) (72) before calling the GetMonitorInfo function. Doing so lets the function determine the type of structure you are passing to it.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.MONITORINFOEX.Monitor
member.summary: A RECT structure that specifies the display monitor rectangle, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.MONITORINFOEX.WorkArea
member.summary: A RECT structure that specifies the work area rectangle of the display monitor that can be used by applications, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Windows uses this rectangle to maximize an application on the monitor. The rest of the area in rcMonitor contains system windows such as the task bar and side bars. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.MONITORINFOEX.Flags
member.summary:
The attributes of the display monitor.
This member can be the following value: 1 : MONITORINFOF_PRIMARY

member.name: F:WinUtilities.WinAPI.MONITORINFOEX.DeviceName
member.summary: A string that specifies the device name of the monitor being used. Most applications have no use for a display monitor name, and so can save some bytes by using a MONITORINFO structure.

member.name: M:WinUtilities.Input.Send(System.String,WinUtilities.SendMode)
member.summary: Send text input.
member.remarks:
The is parsed for special input when between [ and ]. This behaviour can be escaped with [[ and ]].
Any entity, a single character or a special input [], can be preceded with a modifier set like: [+!][Enter] -> Shift + Alt + Enter -OR- [#]p -> Win + P.
The modifiers supported are RShift(+), RCtrl(^), LAlt(!) or RWin(#).
The general layout of normal special input is [key up/down (amount) text] where anything besides the key can be omitted or included as needed.
Specifying up or down will send only that event, instead of sending both down and up events.
Specifying 'text' in the special input sends the 'key' as text instead. For example [Enter 5] sends the Enter key five times but [Enter 5 text] sends the text 'Enter' 5 times.
While using 'text' the 'key' part must not contain any spaces. This makes sending long text difficult, but is useful in sending a specific symbol many times, like [ 10 text].

member.summary: Send raw text input

member.summary: Send char input

The modifiers supported are RShift(+), RCtrl(^), LAlt(!) or RWin(#).
